Translator: Joseph Geni
Reviewer: Morton Bast

15.92.text: So I'd like to start by focusing on

21.19.text: Now, when you talk about dangerous animals,

23.35.text: most people might think of lions or tigers or sharks.

26.40.text: But of course the most dangerous animal

29.94.text: The mosquito has killed more humans

32.10.text: than any other creature in human history.

35.09.text: In fact, probably adding them all together,

37.08.text: the mosquito has killed more humans.

39.26.text: And the mosquito has killed more humans than wars

43.62.text: And you would think, would you not,

46.19.text: that with all our science, with all our advances in society,

50.14.text: with better towns, better civilizations, better sanitation,

55.05.text: wealth, that we would get better at controlling mosquitos,

60.94.text: And that's not really the case.

64.29.text: If it was the case, we wouldn't have

66.41.text: between 200 and 300 million cases of malaria every year,

72.72.text: a million and a half deaths from malaria,

76.66.text: and we wouldn't have a disease

79.36.text: that was relatively unknown 50 years ago

84.73.text: the largest mosquito-borne virus threat that we have,

90.65.text: So 50 years ago, pretty much no one had heard of it,

93.38.text: no one certainly in the European environment.

96.38.text: But dengue fever now, according to the World Health Organization,

100.01.text: infects between 50 and 100 million people every year,

103.50.text: so that's equivalent to the whole of the population

105.83.text: of the U.K. being infected every year.

108.76.text: Other estimates put that number at roughly double

115.83.text: And dengue fever has grown in speed quite phenomenally.

120.27.text: In the last 50 years, the incidence of dengue

125.53.text: Now let me tell you a little bit about what dengue fever is,

129.62.text: Now let's assume you go on holiday.

131.83.text: Let's assume you go to the Caribbean,

133.60.text: or you might go to Mexico. You might go to Latin America,

135.99.text: Asia, Africa, anywhere in Saudi Arabia.

139.95.text: You might go to India, the Far East.

141.67.text: It doesn't really matter. It's the same mosquito,

144.28.text: and it's the same disease. You're at risk.

147.20.text: And let's assume you're bitten by a mosquito

151.43.text: Well, you could develop flu-like symptoms.

158.31.text: your muscles could feel like they're contracting,

160.75.text: and you could actually feel like your bones are breaking.

164.83.text: And that's the nickname given to this disease.

168.65.text: because that's how you can feel.

170.99.text: Now the odd thing is, is that once you've been bitten

173.93.text: by this mosquito, and you've had this disease,

178.81.text: so if you're bitten again with that strain,

184.94.text: But it's not one virus, it's four,

187.86.text: and the same protection that gives you the antibodies

190.84.text: and protects you from the same virus that you had before

194.15.text: actually makes you much more susceptible to the other three.

197.22.text: So the next time you get dengue fever,

199.95.text: if it's a different strain, you're more susceptible,

202.59.text: you're likely to get worse symptoms,

205.22.text: and you're more likely to get the more severe forms,

211.09.text: So you don't want dengue once,

212.51.text: and you certainly don't want it again.

215.25.text: So why is it spreading so fast?

218.53.text: And the answer is this thing.

222.40.text: Now this is a mosquito that came, like its name suggests,

225.61.text: out of North Africa, and it's spread round the world.

229.05.text: Now, in fact, a single mosquito will only travel

232.18.text: about 200 yards in its entire life. They don't travel very far.

235.91.text: What they're very good at doing is hitchhiking,

239.70.text: They will lay their eggs in clear water, any pool, any puddle,

246.35.text: anywhere there's clear water, they'll lay their eggs,

249.09.text: and if that clear water is near freight, it's near a port,

255.36.text: those eggs will then get transported around the world.

258.55.text: And that's what's happened. Mankind has transported

260.97.text: these eggs all the way around the world,

262.97.text: and these insects have infested over 100 countries,

266.67.text: and there's now 2.5 billion people living in countries

272.36.text: To give you just a couple of examples

276.46.text: in the mid-'70s, Brazil declared, "We have no Aedes aegypti,"

281.98.text: and currently they spend about a billion dollars now

284.33.text: a year trying to get rid of it, trying to control it,

292.23.text: Two days ago, or yesterday, I can't remember which,

295.77.text: I saw a Reuters report that said

297.74.text: Madeira had had their first cases of dengue,

300.37.text: about 52 cases, with about 400 probable cases.

306.00.text: Interestingly, Madeira first got the insect in 2005,

311.19.text: and here we are, a few years later,

314.57.text: So the one thing you'll find is that where the mosquito goes,

320.24.text: Once you've got the mosquito in your area,

322.43.text: anyone coming into that area with dengue,

324.80.text: mosquito will bite them, mosquito will bite somewhere else,

332.82.text: So we must be good at killing mosquitos.

334.73.text: I mean, that can't be very difficult.

339.45.text: The first way is that you use larvicides.

342.82.text: You use chemicals. You put them into water where they breed.

345.63.text: Now in an urban environment, that's extraordinarily difficult.

348.43.text: You've got to get your chemical into every puddle,

355.91.text: The second way you can do it

357.42.text: is actually trying to kill the insects as they fly around.

360.74.text: This is a picture of fogging.

365.41.text: is mixing up chemical in a smoke

368.32.text: and basically spreading that through the environment.

371.34.text: You could do the same with a space spray.

375.87.text: and if it was any good, we wouldn't have this massive increase

378.27.text: in mosquitos and we wouldn't have this massive increase in dengue fever.

382.92.text: So it's not very effective, but it's probably

385.01.text: the best thing we've got at the moment.

387.91.text: Having said that, actually, your best form of protection

390.06.text: and my best form of protection is a long-sleeve shirt

392.44.text: and a little bit of DEET to go with it.

395.87.text: So let's start again. Let's design a product,

399.56.text: right from the word go, and decide what we want.

402.83.text: Well we clearly need something that is effective

407.74.text: There's no point in just killing the odd mosquito here and there.

410.17.text: We want something that gets that population right the way down

413.26.text: so it can't get the disease transmission.

416.28.text: Clearly the product you've got has got to be safe to humans.

419.58.text: We are going to use it in and around humans.

423.32.text: We don't want to have a lasting impact on the environment.

425.55.text: We don't want to do anything that you can't undo.

428.78.text: Maybe a better product comes along in 20, 30 years.

433.88.text: Fine. We don't want a lasting environmental impact.

436.75.text: We want something that's relatively cheap, or cost-effective,

440.02.text: because there's an awful lot of countries involved,

441.98.text: and some of them are emerging markets,

443.98.text: some of them emerging countries, low-income.

447.54.text: And finally, you want something that's species-specific.

449.92.text: You want to get rid of this mosquito that spreads dengue,

452.71.text: but you don't really want to get all the other insects.

455.69.text: Some are quite beneficial. Some are important to your ecosystem.

458.91.text: This one's not. It's invaded you.

460.75.text: But you don't want to get all of the insects.

463.43.text: You just want to get this one.

465.09.text: And most of the time, you'll find this insect

467.95.text: lives in and around your home,

469.38.text: so this -- whatever we do has got to get to that insect.

473.31.text: It's got to get into people's houses, into the bedrooms,

477.48.text: Now there are two features of mosquito biology

481.13.text: that really help us in this project,

483.03.text: and that is, firstly, males don't bite.

486.90.text: It's only the female mosquito that will actually bite you.

490.01.text: The male can't bite you, won't bite you,

492.41.text: doesn't have the mouth parts to bite you.

496.37.text: And the second is a phenomenon

498.35.text: that males are very, very good at finding females.

502.56.text: If there's a male mosquito that you release,

505.21.text: and if there's a female around, that male will find the female.

510.05.text: So basically, we've used those two factors.

515.54.text: male meets female, lots of offspring.

518.11.text: A single female will lay about

519.84.text: up to 100 eggs at a time,

521.63.text: up to about 500 in her lifetime.

524.12.text: Now if that male is carrying a gene

527.14.text: which causes the death of the offspring,

532.44.text: and instead of having 500 mosquitos running around,

538.49.text: And if you can put more, I'll call them sterile,

541.61.text: that the offspring will actually die at different stages,

544.48.text: but I'll call them sterile for now.

546.07.text: If you put more sterile males out into the environment,

549.62.text: then the females are more likely to find a sterile male

552.91.text: than a fertile one, and you will bring that population down.

558.75.text: So the males will go out, they'll look for females,

561.15.text: they'll mate. If they mate successfully, then no offspring.

564.97.text: If they don't find a female, then they'll die anyway.

567.97.text: They only live a few days.

571.71.text: And that's exactly where we are.

573.94.text: So this is technology that was developed

575.57.text: in Oxford University a few years ago.

578.12.text: The company itself, Oxitec, we've been working

580.54.text: for the last 10 years, very much on a sort of similar

583.09.text: development pathway that you'd get with a pharmaceutical company.

586.54.text: So about 10 years of internal evaluation, testing,

590.65.text: to get this to a state where we think it's actually ready.

594.04.text: And then we've gone out into the big outdoors,

600.31.text: So we've done field trials now in the Cayman Islands,

604.92.text: and two more now in Brazil.

610.99.text: Well, the result has been very good.

614.30.text: In about four months of release,

617.12.text: we've brought that population of mosquitos

619.42.text: — in most cases we're dealing with villages here

621.96.text: of about 2,000, 3,000 people, that sort of size,

626.67.text: we've taken that mosquito population down

628.86.text: by about 85 percent in about four months.

632.08.text: And in fact, the numbers after that get,

634.08.text: those get very difficult to count, because there just aren't any left.

637.82.text: So that's been what we've seen in Cayman,

639.48.text: it's been what we've seen in Brazil

644.73.text: And now what we're doing is we're going through a process

647.04.text: to scale up to a town of about 50,000,

649.87.text: so we can see this work at big scale.

652.24.text: And we've got a production unit in Oxford,

655.03.text: or just south of Oxford, where we actually produce these mosquitos.

659.73.text: in a space a bit more than this red carpet,

661.88.text: I can produce about 20 million a week.

664.41.text: We can transport them around the world.

666.57.text: It's not very expensive, because it's a coffee cup --

669.59.text: something the size of a coffee cup

670.88.text: will hold about three million eggs.

674.21.text: So freight costs aren't our biggest problem. (Laughter)

678.03.text: So we've got that. You could call it a mosquito factory.

681.33.text: And for Brazil, where we've been doing some trials,

684.43.text: the Brazilian government themselves have now built

686.32.text: their own mosquito factory, far bigger than ours,

688.75.text: and we'll use that for scaling up in Brazil.

694.22.text: There you are. We've sent mosquito eggs.

696.60.text: We've separated the males from the females.

699.23.text: The males have been put in little pots

702.88.text: and the truck is going down the road

704.96.text: and they are releasing males as they go.

707.93.text: It's actually a little bit more precise than that.

709.58.text: You want to release them so that

711.06.text: you get good coverage of your area.

713.14.text: So you take a Google Map, you divide it up,

715.93.text: work out how far they can fly,

717.81.text: and make sure you're releasing such that you get

719.79.text: coverage of the area, and then you go back,

722.69.text: and within a very short space of time,

724.46.text: you're bringing that population right the way down.

728.04.text: We've also done this in agriculture.

730.47.text: We've got several different species of agriculture coming along,

736.45.text: we'll be able to get some funding together so we can get back

742.33.text: So that's where we stand at the moment,

744.38.text: and I've just got a few final thoughts,

746.90.text: which is that this is another way in which biology

750.35.text: is now coming in to supplement chemistry

754.34.text: in some of our societal advances in this area,

758.08.text: and these biological approaches are coming in

762.77.text: and when you think about genetic engineering,

765.09.text: we've now got enzymes for industrial processing,

768.10.text: enzymes, genetically engineered enzymes in food.

771.03.text: We have G.M. crops, we have pharmaceuticals,

775.15.text: all using roughly the same technology, but with very different outcomes.

779.23.text: And I'm in favor, actually. Of course I am.

782.75.text: I'm in favor of particularly where the older technologies

785.64.text: don't work well or have become unacceptable.

788.71.text: And although the techniques are similar,

792.07.text: the outcomes are very, very different,

793.61.text: and if you take our approach, for example,

795.13.text: and you compare it to, say, G.M. crops,

797.55.text: both techniques are trying to produce a massive benefit.

803.99.text: which is that we reduce pesticide use tremendously.

807.70.text: But whereas a G.M. crop is trying to protect the plant,

811.66.text: for example, and give it an advantage,

814.40.text: what we're actually doing is taking the mosquito

817.50.text: and giving it the biggest disadvantage it can possibly have,

821.58.text: rendering it unable to reproduce effectively.

824.57.text: So for the mosquito, it's a dead end.
